Award.AwardTitle: Calcium and strontium isotopes as indicators of recrystallization rates in marine carbonates: Implications for geochemical proxies
Award.AbstractNarration:
Researchers from Penn State University will test the hypothesis that recrystallization rates in "young" (i.e, less that one million years old) nannofossil ooze carbonates are significantly faster, and alteration of geochemical proxies much greater, than previously thought. This work will conduct calcium and strontium isotope measurements on marine carbonates and pore fluids and use a numerical diagenetic model to constrain carbonate recrystallization rates in marine systems. The work will extend such measurements from a few Ocean Drilling Program (ODP) sites previously measured, approximately doubling the number of sites examined. The goal is to ascertain if so-called rapid recrystallization extends to other locations in the ocean; if it does, rapid recrystallization may be considered to be a widespread eﬀect of global significance. Researchers will collect archived ODP samples, measure their isotopic composition, and use numerical reactive transport models to interpret diagenetic rates of recrystallization and, critically, evaluate alternate hypotheses.

If rapid recrystallization is conﬁrmed, the proposed work will create a framework for evaluating diagenetic alteration in a range of proxy systems (such as boron and magnesium), and suggest methods for correcting records used to study climate and geochemical evolution on Earth. This work has the potential to produce more accurate proxy records and increase our understanding of the uncertainty of geochemical proxy records, as well as to enable more accurate climate records with which to calibrate climate models used to predict future climate change. The funded research supports a recently-completed NSF-supported multiple-collector ICP-MS facility at Penn State University. Funding also supports education and training of a graduate student, research experiences for undergraduates, and the generation of outreach materials to be displayed at the Penn State Earth and Minerals Sciences Museum.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Geoscientists use marine sediments as recorders of past conditions at the Earth’s surface; these so-called geochemical “proxies” have proven useful for reconstructing sea surface temperatures (e.g., Mg/Ca, alkenones, TEX86), glacial ice volume (O isotopes), surface ocean pH (B isotopes), the rise of atmospheric oxygen (Mo and U isotopes), and elemental cycling over long time scales or in response to rapid climatic events (C, Os, Ca, Sr, Mg isotopes). Proxies are invaluable tools for examining the geochemical and climatic history of Earth and other planets, and add to our understanding of how planetary surfaces function as systems and evolve chemically over time. Accordingly, proxies are critical to putting modern-day climate change in context. Questions, such as “is the present climate changing faster than in the past?” and “how did the Earth system recover from rapid climate change in the past”, can only be answered if we can peer accurately into the past. It is therefore imperative that the tools we use are unaffected by post-depositional processes; if they are altered, it is critical that we understand the extent to which they are affected.

Accordingly, the primary aim of the funded research was to quantify the impact of post-depositional processes on developing proxies, such as Mg isotopes and Na/Ca, as well as more established proxies, such as Sr/Ca and Mg/Ca. This was accomplished by examining solid-fluid interactions at a range of time scales and at multiple sedimentary columns in the ocean. Through the measurements of Ca, Sr, and Mg isotopes, and the application of reactive transport models, we were able to confirm that young (< 1 Ma) carbonates recrystallize more rapidly than previously thought (Fantle, 2015; Chanda et al., in prep). This result is important because it demonstrates that the enhanced rate of recrystallization that was inferred at Site 807A by Fantle and DePaolo (2007) is a robust feature that is also seen at Sites 1170, 1171, and 806. Knowing such rates is critical for understanding how diagenetic alteration proceeds as a function of age/depth in the sedimentary column. Also, once rates are quantified, diagenetic effects can be corrected for. This is invaluable from a proxy perspective, and also helps to quantify proxy uncertainty. This work also was able to quantify the diagenetic effect for Mg isotopes, Sr/Ca, Mg/Ca, and Na/Ca (Chanda and Fantle, 2017; Chanda et al., in prep). This result is important because it unambiguously characterizes the diagenetic fingerprint for trace elements and isotopic systems that are commonly used as proxies. In this contribution, we also consider how the information gleaned about bulk sediment alteration during diagenesis may impact the interpretation of picked proxy archives such as foraminiferal tests. We also quantified the extent to which foraminiferal tests exchanged over laboratory time scales (Chanda et al., in prep.), one of the first studies ever to have done this. This result is important because it helps to understand how foraminiferal tests, which are the dominant picked proxy archive in the Cenozoic, react with fluid. This result is also applicable to alteration that takes place in the marine water column, at core tops (thereby affecting empirical calibrations), and potentially also in laboratory calibration studies. Finally, we confirmed that the numerical approach taken to interpret recrystallization rates is robust (Huber et al., 2017). This result is important because previous efforts at quantifying recrystallization rates have made assumptions during modeling. These assumptions can impact the interpretation of rate. This work evaluated this by deriving an analytical solution to the diagenetic equations (which is provided to the scientific community to use) and investigating the impact of parameters such as burial rate, advection velocity, and porosity on the recrystallization rate and integrated extent of reaction. This work showed that previous conclusions regarding recrystallization in carbonate-rich sections were not impacted by assumptions made, but that work at siliciclastic sites may have been (Turchyn and DePaolo, 2011). Specifically, we found that previous rates at Site 984 were too low by a factor of 10; thus, while siliciclastic sites remain better sites at which to sample carbonates in some regards, alteration in these sites may not be negligible. Finally, we discuss the potential for diagenesis to alter complementary paleotemperature proxies (δ18O and Mg/Ca) in a differential manner. This exploration is critical, as oxygen isotopes and Mg/Ca are complementary paleo-temperature proxies that are often used together to deduce information regarding changes in water mass δ18O. If these two proxies are altered differentially, then this has important ramifications for conclusions made in the past based on a comparison of these proxies.
